name: Upper Cervical (Atlas-Axis)
description: The atlanto-axial joint allowing head rotation. Critical for vestibular function, eye-cervical relationships, and concussion recovery.
anatomical_notes: 90% of cervical rotation occurs at C1-C2. Vertebral artery considerations critical.
evidence: Strong mechanistic support for cervico-ocular reflex optimization

name: Mid-Cervical
description: Common site of cervical disc pathology and nerve root compression affecting shoulder and arm.
anatomical_notes: Nerve roots C5 (deltoid/biceps) and C6 (wrist extensors) exit here. High disc degeneration prevalence.
evidence: Clinical studies show 40-60% pain reduction in VAS scores

name: Cervicothoracic Junction
description: Critical transition zone where mobile cervical spine meets rigid thoracic cage. Stress concentration and injury susceptibility site.
anatomical_notes: Half the flexibility of cervical spine. Curvature reversal from lordosis to kyphosis. Critical for overhead athletes.
evidence: Strong biomechanical rationale for baseball/softball players (thoracolumbar asymmetries)

name: Thoracolumbar Junction
description: Accounts for 25-50% of traumatic spinal fractures. Fulcrum between inflexible thoracic and mobile lumbar regions.
anatomical_notes: Transition from fixed ribs to mobile lumbar. High rotational stress in athletes. Diaphragm attachment at T12.
evidence: Biomechanical studies on junction vulnerability + clinical outcomes

name: Lower Lumbar
description: Second most common site of disc herniation. Greatest height decrease after prolonged sitting (4+ hours).
anatomical_notes: Sitting increases intradiscal pressure 30% vs standing. Creep deformation occurs within 2-4 hours.
evidence: RCT showing superiority to McKenzie exercises for non-specific low back pain

name: Lumbosacral Junction
description: Bears highest loads in spine. Steeper disc inclination increases shear stresses. Most common site of disc herniation and spondylolysis.
anatomical_notes: Highest loads in spine. L5 nerve root exits here (dorsiflexion weakness sign). Disc inclination creates shear stress.
evidence: Strong clinical evidence + biomechanical validation. Proven benefits for athletes (basketball landing forces 1,066 lbs)
